page.title: 10COASTLINE:-COMPTON BAY
page.content: The cliffs of{Compton Bay}are imposing, to say the least. They are made of a sequence of clays and marls. The first bed found,the Wealden, contains a purple marl with sandstone followed by a blue shale. A stratum of red and white clay with lignite is next in sequence. Also in the Wealden bed is a great slip of Atherfield clay and Wealden shales. Following this is a stratum of chalky beds with springs thrown out by the sandrock stratum. At the base of the cliffs is a layer of Glauconitic marl and chert beds. The cliffs are therefore of great interest to geologists. The bay is also very popular with tourists as it is one of the best places to swim on the{ISLE OF WIGHT.
